conclusion: The problem asks how shadows A, B, C, and D will change in position when the light source moves to the back-left above the objects.
Because the lamp is now high at the back-left, every shadow must fall in the opposite direction: down-screen (toward the viewer/front) and a little to the right.
The silhouette of each object stays the same, but its dark patch slides and lengthens along the front-right diagonal.
Object A is a white cloth with a shadow almost straight beneath it.
The shadow of object A will shift so that the dark patch appears a little farther away from the cloth, down and right.
Object B is a round make-up mirror with a small roundish shadow under its base.
The shadow of object B will move down and to the right of the stand; because the mirror is tall, the shadow will lengthen most noticeably of the four objects.
Object C is a ring with a narrow ring-shaped shadow that appears as a thin oval.
The shadow of object C will still be a thin oval, but now the oval lies slightly down-right from the metal ring instead of almost underneath it.
Object D is an avocado with a short, squat shadow.
The shadow of object D will slide down-right of the fruit, with the long axis of the blur pointing roughly toward the bottom-right corner.

With the light now high at the back-left, every shadow (A, B, C, D) moves to the front-right of its object, becoming a little longer; their relative forms stay the same but their positions all shift along that common direction.
